# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia code implementing your requirements:
```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump::Int=3)
    dt += Hour(bump)
end

try
    date = DateTime("2021-10-15T14:30")
    result = timezone_bumper(date)
    println(result)
catch e
    if isa(e, MethodError)
        @info "Please input a DateTime type."
    else
        rethrow(e)
    end
end
```
This function will throw an error when you attempt to call it with Date instead of DateTime. If you provide DateTime argument, the function will increase time by `bump` hours and print out the result. 

Here, I am using Dates package for handling dates in Julia. Hour() function is used for increasing date-time by given number of hours.
